text: Let the redeemed of the LORD say so, whom he hath redeemed from the hand of the enemy;
text_kjv: Let the redeemed of the LORD say so, whom he hath redeemed from the hand of the enemy;
text_niv: Let the redeemed of the Lord say this—those he redeemed from the hand of the foe,
text_esv: Let the redeemed of the LORD say so, whom he has redeemed from trouble
text_nlt: Has the LORD redeemed you? Then speak out!Tell others he has redeemed you from your enemies.
text_msg: All of you set free by God, tell the world!Tell how he freed you from oppression,
text_nasb: Let the redeemed of the LORD say [so], Whom He has redeemed from the hand of the adversary
context: Psalm 107 is a psalm of thanksgiving, likely composed for communal worship. Historically, it might have been used during a pilgrimage festival, perhaps after the Babylonian exile when the Israelites returned to their homeland. The phrase 'redeemed of the LORD' strongly suggests a connection to the Exodus narrative, the quintessential act of God's redemption. The 'hand of the enemy' echoes the oppression faced in Egypt and later during the exile. Considering the historical context of Israel's repeated cycles of disobedience, suffering, repentance, and deliverance, this psalm likely served as a powerful reminder of God's enduring covenant faithfulness. The repeated refrain in verses 6, 13, 19, and 28 emphasizes the immediate and available mercy of God in times of distress. This psalm would resonate deeply with individuals and communities facing hardship, reminding them of God's past interventions and encouraging them to trust in His ongoing provision. The inclusion of diverse groups—those wandering in the desert, imprisoned, sick, and caught in storms—suggests a universal appeal, illustrating that redemption is available to all who call upon the Lord. The psalm's structure, moving from the general call to thanksgiving to specific instances of deliverance, reinforces the message that God is both the God of the nation and the God of the individual.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 107:2 is a powerful declaration of God's redemptive character and the believer's responsibility to acknowledge it. The 'redeemed of the LORD' are those who have been bought back, rescued, or liberated from a state of bondage or danger. This redemption isn't just physical; it extends to spiritual liberation from sin and its consequences. The phrase 'say so' underscores the importance of vocal testimony. It's not enough to merely experience God's redemption inwardly; believers are called to openly proclaim it. This declaration serves as both a personal affirmation of faith and a witness to others. The 'hand of the enemy' represents any force that seeks to oppress or destroy God's people, whether it be literal enemies, sin, death, or spiritual darkness. God's redemption is presented as a direct intervention against these forces. This verse connects to the broader biblical theme of covenant, where God promises to protect and deliver His people, and they, in turn, are called to be faithful and to testify to His faithfulness. The act of testifying to God's redemption reinforces the reality of that redemption in the lives of believers and strengthens their faith. It is an act of worship and gratitude, acknowledging God's sovereignty and power over all things. Ultimately, this verse highlights the transformative power of God's grace and the believer's role in proclaiming that grace to the world.
application: In today's world, Psalm 107:2 calls us to a proactive expression of our faith. 'Let the redeemed of the LORD say so' is not a suggestion, but an imperative. We, who have been redeemed from the 'hand of the enemy' – be it addiction, fear, despair, or any other form of bondage – are obligated to voice our experience of God's saving grace. This isn't about boasting, but about bearing witness to the transformative power of God in our lives. Practically, this could mean sharing our testimony in church, with friends and family, or even on social media. It means being open and honest about our struggles and how God has brought us through them. It also means actively seeking opportunities to encourage others who are struggling, reminding them that redemption is possible. Furthermore, this verse challenges us to examine our own lives. Have we truly experienced God's redemption? Are we living as though we have been set free? If not, it's a call to repentance and a renewed commitment to following Christ. Saying 'so' also involves living a life that reflects our redemption. Our actions should align with our words, demonstrating the love, grace, and mercy that we have received from God. It means forgiving others as we have been forgiven, extending compassion to those in need, and standing up for justice and righteousness. In essence, 'saying so' is not just about talking; it's about living a life that proclaims the gospel. Let us then, as the redeemed of the Lord, boldly and consistently declare His goodness in word and deed, that others may come to know the liberating power of His love.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your incredible gift of redemption. We acknowledge that we were once lost, bound by sin and darkness, but you, in your infinite mercy, reached down and rescued us. Help us to never take this gift for granted. Give us the courage to 'say so,' to openly and honestly share our testimonies with others, that they too may experience the freedom and joy of your salvation. Lord, break any chains that still bind us, any fears that hold us back from fully embracing our identity as your redeemed children. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that our words and actions may reflect your love and grace to the world. Use us as instruments of your peace, to bring hope to the hopeless and healing to the brokenhearted. We pray all this in the name of Jesus, our Redeemer. Amen.

faqs.answer: To be redeemed signifies being bought back or rescued from a state of bondage, whether physical, spiritual, or emotional. It implies a price was paid for our freedom, referring to Jesus Christ's sacrifice for our sins on the cross.

faqs.answer: The 'enemy' can refer to various forces, including Satan, sin, death, and any power that seeks to oppress or separate us from God's love and purpose. It represents anything that hinders our relationship with God.
faqs.question: Q2: Who is the 'enemy' referred to in this verse?

faqs.answer: Saying so is an act of witness and affirmation. It strengthens our own faith, proclaims God's goodness to others, and invites others to experience His redemptive power. Silence can diminish the impact of God's work.
faqs.question: Q3: Why is it important to 'say so' and not just believe it?

faqs.answer: You can 'say so' by sharing your testimony, offering encouragement to others, expressing gratitude for God's blessings, and living a life that reflects His love and grace in your interactions and choices.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I practically 'say so' in my daily life?

faqs.answer: Redemption is a process, not a destination. Even a small step toward freedom is worth celebrating. Focus on God's faithfulness in your life, and trust that He will continue to work in you. Your vulnerability can be powerful.
